revision.comment: Added free to read link in citations with [[WP:OABOT|OAbot]] #oabot
revision.text:
{{short description|Possibly a type of Luminous Blue Compact Galaxy which is undergoing very high rates of star formation}} [[File:Cardamone Peas.jpg|thumb|Galaxy Zoo Green Peas]] [[File:Hubble Peas Ed.jpg|thumb|Three Hubble Space Telescope pictures of Green Peas]]
A '''Pea galaxy''', also referred to as a '''Pea''' or '''Green Pea''', might be a type of Luminous [[Starburst galaxy|Blue Compact Galaxy]] which is undergoing very high rates of [[star formation]].<ref name=gzdiscovery>{{ cite journal| author1=C. Cardamone| author2=K. Schawinski| author3=M. Sarzi| author4=S.P. Bamford| author5=N. Bennert| author6=C.M. Urry| author7=C. Lintott| author8=W.C. Keel| author9=J. Parejko| author10=R.C. Nichol| author11=D. Thomas| author12=D. Andreescu| author13=P. Murray| author14=M.J. Raddick| author15=A. Slosar| author16=A. Szalay| author17=J. Vandenberg| date=December 2009 | title=Galaxy Zoo Green Peas: Discovery of A Class of Compact Extremely Star-Forming Galaxies | journal=[[Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society]] | volume=399 |issue=3 |pages=1191–1205 | bibcode=2009MNRAS.399.1191C | doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2009.15383.x | arxiv=0907.4155 }}</ref> Pea galaxies are so-named because of their small size and greenish appearance in the images taken by the [[Sloan Digital Sky Survey]] (SDSS).
Pea Galaxies were first discovered in 2007 by the volunteer [[citizen scientists]] within the forum section of the online [[astronomy]] project [[Galaxy Zoo]] (GZ), part of the [[Zooniverse]] [[web portal]].<ref name=MJR_10>{{cite journal| author1=M.J. Raddick| author2=G. Bracey| author3=P.L. Gay| author4=C.J. Lintott| author5=P. Murray| author6=K. Schawinski| author7=A.S. Szalay| author8=J. Vandenberg| title=Galaxy Zoo:Exploring the motivations of citizen science volunteers| journal=[[American Astronomical Society|Astronomy Education Review]] | date=2010| volume=9 |issue=1 |page=010103 | bibcode=2010AEdRv...9a0103R | doi=10.3847/AER2009036 | arxiv=0909.2925}}</ref><ref name=M.S._1/><ref name="nielsen">{{Cite book |title=Reinventing Discovery: The New Era of Networked Science |last= Nielsen |first=M. |date=2011 |publisher=[[Princeton University Press]] |isbn=978-0-691-14890-8}}</ref>
== Description ==
The Pea galaxies, also known as Green Peas (GPs), are compact oxygen-rich emission line [[galaxy]] that were discovered at [[redshift]] between ''z'' = 0.112 and 0.360.<ref name=gzdiscovery/> These low-mass galaxies have an upper size limit generally no bigger than {{convert|16300|ly|pc|lk=on}} across, and typically they reside in environments less than two-thirds the density of normal galaxy environments.<ref name=gzdiscovery/> An average GP has a redshift of ''z'' = 0.258, a mass of ~3,200 million {{Solar mass}} (~3,200 million solar masses), a star formation rate of {{Solar mass|~10}}/yr (~10 solar masses a year), an [[Doubly ionized oxygen|[O III]]] [[equivalent width]] of 69.4 [[nanometre|nm]] and a low [[metallicity]].<ref name=gzdiscovery/><ref name="Amorin 2010">{{cite journal| author=R. O. Amorín| author2=E. Pérez-Montero| author3=J.M. Vílchez| title=On the oxygen and nitrogen chemical abundances and the evolution of the "green pea" galaxies| journal=The Astrophysical Journal Letters| volume=715| issue=2| bibcode=2010ApJ...715L.128A| doi=10.1088/2041-8205/715/2/L128| arxiv=1004.4910| pages=L128–L132| year=2010}}</ref> A GP is purely star-forming, rather than having an [[Active galactic nucleus]]. They have a strong emission line at the [OIII] [[wavelength]] of 500.7 nm. [OIII], O<sup>++</sup> or [[doubly ionized oxygen]], is a [[Forbidden mechanism]] of the [[visible spectrum]] and is only possible at very low [[density]].<ref name=gzdiscovery/><ref name=gzyale>{{cite web| date=July 27, 2009 | title=Galaxy Zoo Hunters Help Astronomers Discover Rare 'Green Pea' Galaxies | url=http://news.yale.edu/2009/07/27/galaxy-zoo-hunters-help-astronomers-discover-rare-green-pea-galaxies | work=[[Yale University|Yale News]] | accessdate=2009-12-29 }}</ref> When the entire photometric SDSS catalogue was searched, 40,222 objects were returned, which leads to the conclusion the GPs are rare objects.<ref name=gzdiscovery/>
GPs are the least massive and most actively star-forming galaxies in the local universe.<ref name=nakajima>{{ cite journal |author=K. Nakajima |author2=M. Ouchi |last-author-amp=yes| date=2014| title=Ionization state of inter-stellar medium in galaxies: evolution, SFR-M*-Z dependence, and ionizing photon escape| journal=[[Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society]]| volume=442| issue=1| pages=900–916| bibcode=2014MNRAS.442..900N| doi=10.1093/mnras/stu902| arxiv=1309.0207 }}</ref> "These galaxies would have been normal in the early Universe, but we just don’t see such [[Active galactic nucleus|active galaxies]] today", said [[Kevin Schawinski]]. "Understanding the Green Peas may tell us something about how stars were formed in the early Universe and how galaxies evolve".<ref name=gzyale/>
GPs exist at a time when the [[Universe]] was three-quarters of its present age and so are clues as to how [[Galaxy formation and evolution]] took place in the early Universe.<ref>{{ cite web | date=2003 | title=New Image of Infant Universe reveals era of first stars, age of cosmos, and more | url=http://www.nasa.gov/centers/goddard/news/topstory/2003/0206mapresults.html | publisher=[[NASA]] | accessdate=2010-01-16 }}</ref> With the publication of Amorin's GTC paper in February 2012, it is now thought that GPs might be old galaxies having formed most of their stellar mass several billion years ago. Old stars have been spectroscopically confirmed in one of the three galaxies in the study by the presence of [[Magnesium]].<ref name=Amorin_GTC />
[[File:GP J1219 NearUV HST.jpg| thumb| A [[Hubble Space Telescope]] [[Cosmic Origins Spectrograph]] Near-UV image of Pea galaxy GP_J1219.]] In January 2016, a study was published in the journal [[Nature (journal)|Nature]] identifying J0925+1403 as a [[Lyman continuum photons]] (LyC) 'leaker' with an escape fraction of ~8% (see section below).<ref name=J0925_Nature/> A follow-up study using the same [[Hubble Space Telescope]] (HST) data identifies four more LyC leakers, described as GPs.<ref name=Detect_LyC>{{cite journal| title=Detection of high Lyman continuum leakage from four low-redshift compact star-forming galaxies| author1=Y. I. Izotov| author2=D. Schaerer| author3=T. X. Thuan| author4=G. Worseck| author5=N. G. Guseva| author6=I. Orlitova| author7=A. Verhamme| journal=MNRAS| volume=461| issue=4| pages= 3683–3701| date=October 2016| doi=10.1093/mnras/stw1205| arxiv=1605.05160| bibcode=2016MNRAS.461.3683I}}</ref> In 2014-15, two separate sources identified two other GPs to be likely LyC leaking candidates (J1219 and J0815), suggesting that these two GPs are also low-redshift analogs of high-redshift Lyman-alpha and LyC leakers.<ref name=nakajima/><ref name=Jaskot_2014(b)>{{cite journal |author=A. E. Jaskot |author2=M. S. Oey |last-author-amp=yes| title=Linking Ly-alpha and Low-Ionization Transitions at Low Optical Depth| date=2014| journal=The Astrophysical Journal Letters| volume=791| issue=2| bibcode=2014ApJ...791L..19J| doi=10.1088/2041-8205/791/2/L19| arxiv=1406.4413 | pages=L19}}</ref><ref name=Verhamme_2015>{{cite journal| author=A. Verhamme |author2=I. Orlitova |author3=D. Schaerer |author4=M. Hayes| title=Using Lyman-alpha to detect galaxies that leak Lyman continuum| journal=Astronomy and Astrophysics| volume=578| date=June 2015| bibcode=2015A&A...578A...7V| doi=10.1051/0004-6361/201423978| arxiv=1404.2958 | pages=A7}}</ref> Finding local LyC leakers is crucial to theories about the early universe and [[reionization]].<ref name=Jaskot_2014(b)/><ref name=Verhamme_2015/> More details here:[[Pea galaxy#J0925+1403 and LyC Leakage|Izotov et al. 2016]]
The image to the right shows Pea galaxy GP_J1219.<ref name=Jaskot_2014(b)/> This was observed in 2014 by a HST team whose Principal Investigator was Alaina Henry, using the [[Cosmic Origins Spectrograph]] and the Near Ultraviolet channel.<ref name=GP_J1219_P13293>{{cite web| title=HST Program 13293| url=http://www.stsci.edu/hst/phase2-public/13293.pro| publisher=[[Space Telescope Science Institute]]| date=5 March 2014| accessdate=24 December 2014}}</ref> The scale bar in the image shows 1 [[Minute and second of arc|arc second]] (1"), which corresponds to ~10,750 light years at the distance of 2.69 billion light years for GP_J1219. When using the COS Multi-Anode Micro-channel Array, in NUV imaging mode, the detector plate scale is ~40 pixels per arcsecond (0.0235 arcseconds per pixel).<ref name=COS_HBk>{{cite web| title=Cosmic Origins Spectrograph Instrument Handbook for Cycle 22| page=COS Quick Reference Guide| url=http://www.stsci.edu/hst/cos/documents/handbooks/current/cos_ihb.pdf| publisher=Space Telescope Science Institute| date=January 2014| accessdate=25 December 2014}}</ref>
== History of discovery ==
===Years 2007 to 2010===
[[Galaxy Zoo]] (GZ) is a project online since July 2007 which seeks to [[Galaxy morphological classification|classify]] up to one million galaxies.<ref name=GZ_Morph>{{cite journal |author=C.J. Lintott |display-authors=4 |author2=K. Schawinski |author3=A. Slosar |author4= K. Land |author5=S. Bamford |author6=D. Thomas |author7=M. Jordan Raddick |author8=R.C. Nichol |author9=A.Szalay |author10=D. Andreescu |author11=P. Murray |author12=J. van den Berg |date=2008 |title=Galaxy Zoo: morphologies derived from visual inspection of galaxies from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey |journal=[[MNRAS]] |volume=389 |issue=3 |bibcode=2008MNRAS.389.1179L |doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2008.13689.x |arxiv=0804.4483 |pages=1179–1189}}</ref><ref name=GZ_1>{{cite journal|title=Galaxy Zoo 1: data release of morphological classifications for nearly 900,000 galaxies |author=C. Lintott |display-authors=4 |author2=K. Schawinski |author3=S. Bamford |author4=A. Slosar |author5=K. Land |author6=D. Thomas |author7=E. Edmondson |author8=K. Masters |author9=R. Nichol |author10=J. Raddick |author11=A. Szalay |author12=D. Andreescu |author13=P. Murray |author14=J. Vandenberg |date=2011 |journal=[[MNRAS]]|volume=410 |issue=1 |bibcode=2011MNRAS.410..166L |doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.17432.x |arxiv=1007.3265 |pages=166–178}}</ref> On July 28, 2007, two days after the start of the Galaxy Zoo [[Internet forum]], citizen scientist 'Nightblizzard' posted two green objects thought to be galaxies.<ref name="nielsen"/> A discussion, or thread, was started on this forum by Hanny Van Arkel on the 12th of August 2007 called "Give peas a chance" in which various green objects were posted.<ref name="nielsen"/> This thread started humorously, as the name is a [[word play]] of the title of the [[John Lennon]] song "[[Give Peace a Chance]]", but by December 2007, it had become clear that some of these unusual objects were a distinct group of galaxies. These "Pea galaxies" appear in the SDSS as unresolved green images. This is because the Peas have a very bright, or powerful, [[Spectral line]] in their spectra for highly-[[ionization|ionized]] [[oxygen]], which in SDSS color composites increases the [[luminosity]], or brightness, of the "r" color band with respect to the two other color bands "g" and "i". The "r" color band shows as green in SDSS images.<ref name=gzdiscovery/><ref>{{cite web |title=SDSS Color |url=http://cas.sdss.org/dr6/en/proj/basic/color/ |accessdate=2010-01-23 |publisher=[[Sloan Digital Sky Survey]]}}</ref> Enthusiasts, calling themselves the "Peas Corps" (another humorous play on the [[Peace Corps]]), collected over a hundred of these Peas, which were eventually placed together into a dedicated [[Conversation threading|discussion thread]] started by Carolin Cardamone in July 2008. The collection, once refined, provided values that could be used in a systematic computer search of the GZ database of one million objects, which eventually resulted in a sample of 251 Pea galaxies, also known as Green Peas (GPs).
In November 2009, authors C. Cardamone, Kevin Schawinski, M. Sarzi, S. Bamford, N. Bennert, C. Urry, [[Chris Lintott]], W. Keel and 9 others published a paper in the [[Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society]] titled "Galaxy Zoo Green Peas: Discovery of A Class of Compact Extremely Star-Forming Galaxies".<ref name=gzdiscovery/> Within this paper, 10 Galaxy Zoo volunteers are acknowledged as having made a particularly significant contribution. They are: Elisabeth Baeten, Gemma Coughlin, Dan Goldstein, Brian Legg, Mark McCallum, Christian Manteuffel, Richard Nowell, Richard Proctor, Alice Sheppard and Hanny Van Arkel. They are thanked for "giving Peas a chance". Citations for 2009MNRAS.399.1191C are available from the SAO/NASA Astrophysics Data System.<ref>{{Cite journal|title= Galaxy Zoo Green Peas: Discovery of a class of compact extremely star-forming galaxies|journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society|volume=399|issue=3|pages=1191–1205|bibcode=2009MNRAS.399.1191C|last1=Cardamone|first1=Carolin|last2=Schawinski|first2=Kevin|last3=Sarzi|first3=Marc|last4=Bamford|first4=Steven P|last5=Bennert|first5=Nicola|last6=Urry|first6=C. M|last7=Lintott|first7=Chris|last8=Keel|first8=William C|last9=Parejko|first9=John|last10=Nichol|first10=Robert C|last11=Thomas|first11=Daniel|last12=Andreescu|first12=Dan|last13=Murray|first13=Phil|last14=Raddick|first14=M. Jordan|last15=Slosar|first15=Anže|last16=Szalay|first16=Alex|last17=Vandenberg|first17=Jan|year=2009|arxiv=0907.4155|doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2009.15383.x}}</ref> More details here:[[Pea galaxy#Physics from the Cardamone 2009 paper|Cardamone 2009 Physics]]
It would be wrong to assume that the 80 GPs were all new discoveries. Out of the 80 original, 46 GPs have previous citations dated before November 2009 in the [[NASA/IPAC Extragalactic Database]]. The original 80 GPs were part of a sample from [[Sloan Digital Sky Survey|SDSS]] data-release 7 (DR7), but did not include galaxies from other sources. Some of these other sources did include objects that might well have been classed as GPs if they were in the SDSS sample. One example of a paper that demonstrates this is: In April 2009, authors J. J. Salzer, A. L. Williams and C. Gronwall published a paper in [[the Astrophysical Journal]] Letters titled "A Population of Metal-Poor Galaxies with ~L* Luminosities at Intermediate Redshifts".<ref name=Salzer_2009>{{cite journal |author=John J. Salzer |author2=Anna L.Williams |author3=Caryl Gronwall |last-author-amp=yes |title=A Population of Metal-Poor Galaxies with ~L* Luminosities at Intermediate Redshifts |date=2009 |journal=The Astrophysical Journal Letters |volume=695 |issue=1 |bibcode=2009ApJ...695L..67S |doi=10.1088/0004-637X/695/1/L67 |arxiv=0903.3948 |pages=L67–L71}}</ref> In this paper, "new spectroscopy and metallicity estimates for a sample of 15 star-forming galaxies with redshifts in the range 0.29 – 0.42" were presented. These objects were selected using the KPNO International Spectroscopic Survey (KISS).<ref name=Salzer_KISS_2000>{{cite journal |author=J. J. Salzer |display-authors=4 |author2=C. Gronwall |author3=V. A. Lipovetsky |author4=A. Kniazev |author5=J. W. Moody |author6=T. A. Boroson |author7=T. X. Thuan |author8=Y. I. Izotov |author9=J. L. Herrero |author10=L. M. Frattare |title=The KPNO International Spectroscopic Survey. I. Description of the Survey |date=2000 |journal=The Astronomical Journal |volume=120 |issue=1 |bibcode=2000AJ....120...80S |doi=10.1086/301418 |arxiv=astro-ph/0004074 |pages=80–94}}</ref> Certainly 3 of these 15 when viewed as objects in SDSS are green (KISSR 1516, KISSR 2042 and KISSRx 467). Indeed, quoting from Salzer et al. 2009, section 4.1, it reads "A New Class of Galaxy? Given the large number of studies of metal abundances in galaxies with intermediate and high redshift mentioned in the Introduction, it may seem odd that systems similar to those described here have not been recognized previously."<ref name=Salzer_2009/>
In June 2010, authors R. Amorin, E. Perez-Montero and J. Vilchez published a paper in [[The Astrophysical Journal]] Letters titled "On the oxygen and nitrogen chemical abundances and the evolution of the "green pea" galaxies".<ref name="Amorin 2010"/> In it they explore issues concerning the [[metallicity]] of 79 GPs, disputing the original findings in Cardamone et al. They conclude, "arguing that recent interaction-induced inflow of gas, possibly coupled with a selective metal-rich gas loss drive by [[supernova]] winds may explain our findings and the known galaxy properties".<ref name="Amorin 2010"/> More details here:[[Pea galaxy#Two Papers by R.Amorin.2C J.M.Vilchez and E.Perez-Montero|Two papers by Amorin]]
===2011===
In February 2011, authors Y. Izotov, N. Guseva and T. Thuan published a paper in the Astrophysical Journal titled "Green Pea Galaxies and Cohorts: Luminous Compact Emission-line Galaxies in the Sloan Digital Sky Survey".<ref name=Izotovetal>{{cite journal |author=Y.I. Izotov |author2=N.G. Guseva |author3=T.X. Thuan |title=Green Pea Galaxies and cohorts: Luminous Compact Emission-Line Galaxies in the Sloan Digital Sky Survey |date=2011 |journal=The Astrophysical Journal |volume=728 |issue=2 |bibcode=2011ApJ...728..161I |doi=10.1088/0004-637X/728/2/161 |arxiv=1012.5639 |pages=161}}</ref> They find that the 80 GPs are not a rare class of galaxies on their own, but rather a subset of a class known as 'Luminous Compact Galaxies' (LCGs), of which there are 803.<ref name=Izotovetal/> More details here:[[Pea galaxy#Comparison of Green Peas to Luminous Compact Galaxies|Luminous Compact Galaxies]]
In November 2011, authors Y. Izotov, N. Guseva, K. Fricke and C. Henkel published a paper in [[Astronomy and Astrophysics]] titled 'Star-forming galaxies with hot dust emission in the SDSS discovered by the [[Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer]] (WISE)'.<ref name=HotDust>{{Cite journal |author=Y.I. Izotov |author2=N.G. Guseva |author3=K.J. Fricke |author4=C. Henkel |last-author-amp=yes |title=Star-forming galaxies with hot dust emission in the Sloan Digital Sky Survey discovered by the Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer (WISE) |date=2011 |journal=Astronomy & Astrophysics |volume=536 |bibcode=2011A&A...536L...7I |doi=10.1051/0004-6361/201118402 |arxiv=1111.5450 |pages=L7}}</ref> In this paper, they find four galaxies that have very red colours in the wavelength range 3.4 micrometres (W1) and 4.6 micrometres (W2). This implies that the dust in these galaxies is at temperatures up to 1000K. These four galaxies are GPs and more than double the number of known galaxies with these characteristics.<ref name=HotDust/>
===2012===
In January 2012, authors R. Amorin, R. Perez-Montero and J.Vilchez published a 'Conference proceeding' titled "Unveiling the Nature of the "Green Pea" galaxies".<ref name=PeaConference>{{cite book |author=R. Amorin |title=Dwarf Galaxies: Keys to Galaxy Formation and Evolution |volume=28 |author2=R. Perez-Montero |author3=J.Vilchez |last-author-amp=yes |date=2012 |pages=243–251 |publisher=Springer |bibcode=2012ASSP...28..243A |doi=10.1007/978-3-642-22018-0_28 |arxiv=1105.1477v1|chapter=Unveiling the Nature of the "Green Pea" Galaxies |series=Astrophysics and Space Science Proceedings |isbn=978-3-642-22017-3 }}</ref> In this publication, they announce that they have conducted a set of observations using the [[Optical System for Imaging and low Resolution Integrated Spectroscopy]] (OSIRIS) at the [[Gran Telescopio Canarias]], and that there is a forthcoming paper about their research. These observations "will provide new insights on the evolutionary state of the Green Peas. In particular, we will be able to see whether the Green Peas show an extended, old stellar population underlying the young starbursts, like those typically dominant in terms of stellar mass in most Blue Compact Galaxies".<ref name=PeaConference/> More details here: [[Pea galaxy#Two Papers by R.Amorin.2C J.M.Vilchez and E.Perez-Montero|Two papers by Amorin]]
In January 2012, authors L. Pilyugin, J. Vilchez, L. Mattsson and T. Thuan published a paper in the [[Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society|MNRAS]] titled: "Abundance determination from global emission-line SDSS spectra: exploring objects with high N/O ratios".<ref name=AbundanceDetermination>{{cite journal |author=L.S. Pilyugin |author2=J.M. Vilchez |author3=L. Mattsson |author4=T.X. Thuan |title=Abundance determination from global emission-line SDSS spectra: exploring objects with high N/O ratios |date=2012 |journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society |volume=421 |issue=2 |bibcode=2012MNRAS.421.1624P |doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2012.20420.x |arxiv=1201.1554 |pages=1624–1634}}</ref> In it they compare the oxygen and nitrogen abundances derived from global emission-line SDSS spectra of galaxies using (1) the electron temperature method and (2) two recent strong line calibrations: the O/N and N/S calibrations.<ref name=AbundanceDetermination/> Three sets of objects were compared: composite hydrogen-rich [[nebula]], 281 SDSS galaxies and a sample of GPs with detectable [OIII]-4363 auroral lines.<ref name=AbundanceDetermination/> Among the questions surrounding the GPs are how much nebulae influence their spectra and results. Through comparisons of the three objects using proven [[methodology]] and analysis of metallicity, they conclude that "the high nitrogen-to-oxygen ratios derived in some Green Pea galaxies may be caused by the fact that their SDSS spectra are spectra of composite nebulae made up of several components with different physical properties (such as metallicity). However, for the hottest Green Pea galaxies, which appear to be dwarf galaxies, this explanation does not seem to be plausible."<ref name=AbundanceDetermination/>
In January 2012, author S. Hawley published a paper in the [[Publications of the Astronomical Society of the Pacific]] titled "Abundances in "Green Pea" Star-forming Galaxies".<ref name=Hawley_Abundances>{{cite journal |author=S.A. Hawley |date=2012 |title=Abundances in Green Pea Star-forming Galaxies |journal=Publications of the Astronomical Society of the Pacific |volume=124 |issue=911 |bibcode=2012PASP..124...21H |doi=10.1086/663866 |pages=21–35}}</ref> In this paper, former NASA astronaut [[Steven Hawley]] compares the results from previous GP papers regarding their metallicities. Hawley compares different ways of calibrating and interpreting the various results, mainly from Cardamone et al. and Amorin et al. but some from Izotov et al., and suggests why the various discrepancies between these papers' findings might be. He also considers such details as the contribution of [[Wolf–Rayet star]]s to the gas ionization, and which sets of emission lines give the most accurate results for these galaxies. He ends by writing: "The calibrations derived from the Green Peas differ from those commonly utilized and would be useful if star-forming galaxies like the Green Peas with extremely hot ionizing sources are found to be more common."<ref name=Hawley_Abundances />
In February 2012, authors S. Chakraborti, N. Yadav, C. Cardamone and A. Ray published a paper in The Astrophysical Journal Letters titled 'Radio Detection of Green Peas: Implications for Magnetic Fields in Young Galaxies'.<ref name=RadioDetection>{{cite journal |author=S. Chakraborti |author2=N. Yadav |author3=C. Cardamone |author4=A. Ray |last-author-amp=yes |date=2012 |title=Radio Detection of Green Peas: Implications for Magnetic Fields in Young Galaxies |journal=The Astrophysical Journal Letters |volume=746 |issue=1 |bibcode=2012ApJ...746L...6C |doi=10.1088/2041-8205/746/1/L6 |arxiv=1110.3312 |pages=L6}}</ref> In this paper, [[magnetism]] studies using new data from the [[Giant Metrewave Radio Telescope]] describe various observations based around the GPs. They show that the three "very young" starburst galaxies that were studied have magnetic fields larger than the Milky Way. This is at odds with the current understanding that galaxies build up their magnetic properties over time.<ref name=RadioDetection/> More details here:[[Pea galaxy#Radio detection of Green Peas|Radio detection]]
In April 2012, authors R. Amorin, E. Perez-Montero, J. Vilchez and P. Papaderos published a paper in the Astrophysical Journal titled "The Star Formation History and Metal Content of the 'Green Peas'. New Detailed GTC-OSIRIS spectrophotometry of Three Galaxies".<ref name=Amorin_GTC>{{cite journal |author=R. Amorin |author2=E. Perez-Montero |author3=J.M. Vilchez |author4=P.Papaderos |title=The star formation history and metal content of the 'Green Peas'. New detailed GTC_OSIRIS spectrophotometry of three galaxies. |date=2012 |journal=The Astrophysical Journal |volume=749 |issue=2 |bibcode=2012ApJ...749..185A |doi=10.1088/0004-637X/749/2/185 |arxiv=1202.3419 |pages=185}}</ref> They give the results for the deep broad-band imaging and long-slit [[spectroscopy]] for 3 GPs that had been observed using the [[Optical System for Imaging and low Resolution Integrated Spectroscopy|OSIRIS]] instrument, mounted on the 10.4m [[Gran Telescopio Canarias]] at the [[Roque de los Muchachos Observatory]].<ref name=Amorin_GTC/> More details here:[[Pea galaxy#GTC-OSIRIS Spectrophotometry|GTC-OSIRIS]]
In August 2012, authors R. Amorín, J. Vílchez, G. Hägele, V. Firpo, E. Pérez-Montero and P. Papaderos published a paper in the Astrophysical Journal Letters titled "Complex gas kinematics in compact, rapidly assembling star-forming galaxies".<ref name=Amorin_Kinematics>{{cite journal |author=R. Amorín |display-authors=4 |author2=J.M. Vílchez |author3=G. Hägele |author4=V. Firpo |author5=E. Pérez-Montero |author6=P. Papaderos |last-author-amp=yes |title=Complex gas kinematics in compact, rapidly assembling star-forming galaxies |date=2012 |journal=The Astrophysical Journal Letters |volume=754 |issue=2 |bibcode=2012ApJ...754L..22A |doi=10.1088/2041-8205/754/2/L22 |arxiv=1207.0509 |pages=L22}}</ref> Using the ISIS spectrograph on the [[William Herschel Telescope]], they publish results of the high-quality spectra that they took of six galaxies, five of which are GPs. After studying the Hydrogen alpha emission lines (ELs) in the spectra of all six, it is shown that these ELs are made up of multiple lines, meaning that the GPs have several chunks of gas and stars moving at large velocities relative to each other. These ELs also show that the GPs are effectively a 'turbulent mess', with parts (or clumps) moving at speeds of over 500 km/s (five hundred km/s) relative to each other.<ref name=Amorin_Kinematics/>
===2013===
In January 2013, authors S. Parnovsky, I. Izotova and Y. Izotov published a paper in [[Astrophysics and Space Science]] titled "H alpha and UV luminosities and star formation rates in a large sample of luminous compact galaxies".<ref name=Parnovsky>{{cite journal |author=S.L. Parnovsky |author2=I.Y. Izotova |author3=Y.I. Izotov |last-author-amp=yes |title=H alpha and UV luminosities and star formation rates in a large sample of luminous compact galaxies |date=2013 |journal=Astrophysics and Space Science |volume=343 |issue=1 |bibcode=2013Ap&SS.343..361P |doi=10.1007/s10509-012-1253-9 |arxiv=1209.3498 |pages=361–376}}</ref> In it, they present a statistical study of the star formation rates (SFR) derived from the [[GALEX]] observations in the Ultraviolet continuum and in the H alpha emission line for a sample of ~800 luminous compact galaxies (LCGs). Within the larger set of LCGs, including the GPs, SFR of up to {{Solar mass|~110}}/yr (~110 solar masses a year) are found, as well as estimates of the ages of the starbursts.<ref name=Parnovsky/>
In April 2013, authors A. Jaskot and M. Oey published a paper in the Astrophysical Journal titled "The Origin and Optical Depth of Ionizing Radiation in the "Green Pea" Galaxies".<ref name=Jaskot>{{cite journal |author=A.E. Jaskot |author2=M.S. Oey |title=The Origin and Optical Depth of Ionizing Radiation in the "Green Pea" Galaxies |date=2013 |journal=The Astrophysical Journal |volume=766 |issue=2 |bibcode=2013ApJ...766...91J |doi=10.1088/0004-637X/766/2/91 |arxiv=1301.0530 |pages=91}}</ref> Six "extreme" GPs are studied. Using these, the authors endeavour to narrow down the list of possibilities about what is producing the radiation and the substantial amounts of high-energy [[photon]] that might be escaping from the GPs.<ref name=Jaskot/> Following on from this paper, observations on the Hubble Space Telescope, totalling 24 orbits, were taken in December 2013.<ref name=Hubble_13293>{{cite web |title=HST OBSERVING PROGRAM 13293 |url=http://www.stsci.edu/hst/phase2-public/13293.pro |accessdate=2014-03-13 |publisher=[[Space Telescope Science Institute]]}}</ref> The Cosmic Origins Spectrograph and the Advanced Camera for Surveys were used on four of the "extreme" GPs. More details here:[[Pea galaxy#Two papers by A. Jaskot and M.S. Oey|Two papers by Jaskot and Oey]]
===2014===
In January 2014, authors Y. Izotov, N. Guseva, K. Fricke and C. Henkel published a paper in Astronomy & Astrophysics entitled "Multi-wavelength study of 14000 star-forming galaxies from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey".<ref name=Izotov_MWS>{{cite journal |author=Y.I. Izotov |author2=N.G. Guseva |author3=K.J. Fricke |author4=C. Henkel |last-author-amp=yes |title=Multi-wavelength study of 14000 star-forming galaxies from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey |date=2014 |journal=Astronomy & Astrophysics |volume=561 |bibcode=2014A&A...561A..33I |doi=10.1051/0004-6361/201322338 |arxiv=1310.1559 |pages=A33}}</ref> In it, they use a variety of sources to demonstrate: "that the emission emerging from young star-forming regions is the dominant dust-heating source for temperatures to several hundred degrees in the sample star-forming galaxies".<ref name=Izotov_MWS/> The first source of data is SDSS from which 14,610 spectra with strong emission lines are selected. These 14,610 spectra were then cross-identified with sources from photometric sky surveys in other wavelength ranges. Those are: 1)[[GALEX]] for the ultraviolet; 2)the [[2MASS]] survey for the near-infrared; 3)the [[Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer]] All-Sky Source Catalog for infrared at differing wavelengths; 4)the [[IRAS]] survey for the far-infrared and the 5)[[NRAO VLA Sky Survey|NVSS]] Survey at radio-wavelengths. Only a small fraction of the SDSS objects were detected in the last two surveys. Among the results is a list of twenty galaxies with the highest magnitudes which have hot dust of several hundred degrees. Of these twenty, all could be classified as GPs and/or LCGs.<ref name=Izotov_MWS/> Also among the results, the [[luminosity]] is obtained in the sample galaxies in a wide wavelength range. At the highest luminosities, the sample galaxies had luminosites approaching those of high-redshift [[Lyman-break galaxy]].<ref name=Izotov_MWS/>
In January 2014, authors A. Jaskot, M. Oey, J. Salzer, A. Van Sistine and M. Haynes gave a presentation titled "Neutral Gas and Low-Redshift Starbursts: From Infall to Ionization" to the [[American Astronomical Society]] at their meeting #223.<ref name=ALFALFA2014>{{cite journal |display-authors=4 |author=A. Jaskot |author2=M. Oey |author3=J. Salzer |author4=A. Van Sistine |author5=M. Haynes |title=Neutral Gas and Low-Redshift Starbursts: From Infall to Ionization |journal=American Astronomical Society Meeting Abstracts #223 |volume=AAS Meeting #223 |pages=328.03 |date=January 2014 |bibcode=2014AAS...22332803J}}</ref> The presentation included data from The [[Arecibo Observatory]] Legacy Fast ALFA Survey (ALFALFA). The authors analyzed the optical spectra of the GPs and concluded "While the ALFALFA survey demonstrates the role of external processes in triggering starbursts, the Green Peas show that starbursts' radiation can escape to affect their external environment", finding "that the Peas are likely optically thin to Lyman continuum (LyC) radiation."<ref name=ALFALFA2014/>
In June 2014, authors A. Jaskot and M. Oey published a conference report titled "The Origin and Optical Depth of Ionizing Photons in the Green Pea Galaxies".<ref name=Jaskot_GH2013>{{Cite book |author=A.E. Jaskot |author2=M.S. Oey |title=The Origin and Optical Depth of Ionizing Photons in the Green Pea Galaxies |date=2014 |journal=2013 Guillermo Haro Conference |pages=171 |isbn=978-607-8379-01-9 |bibcode=2014mysc.conf..171J |arxiv=1402.4429}}</ref> This appears in "Massive Young Star Clusters Near and Far: From the Milky Way to Reionization", based on the 2013 [[Guillermo Haro]] Conference. More details here:[[Pea galaxy#Two papers by A. Jaskot and M.S. Oey|Two papers by Jaskot and Oey]]
===2015===
In May 2015, authors A. Henry, C. Scarlata, C. L. Martin and D. Erb published a paper in the Astrophysical Journal entitled, "Lyα Emission from Green Peas: The Role of Circumgalactic Gas Density, Covering, and Kinematics".<ref name=Henry15>{{cite journal |author=A.L. Henry |author2=C. Scarlata |author3=C. L. Martin |author4=D. Erb |title=Lyα Emission from Green Peas: The Role of Circumgalactic Gas Density, Covering, and Kinematics |date=2015 |journal=Astrophysical Journal |volume=809 |issue=1 |bibcode= 2015ApJ...809...19H|doi=10.1088/0004-637X/809/1/19 |arxiv=1505.05149 |pages=19}}</ref> In this paper, ten Green Peas were studied in the ultraviolet, using high resolution spectroscopy with the Hubble Space Telescope using the Cosmic Origins Spectrograph. This study showed, for the first time, that Green Peas have strong [[Lyman-alpha line|Lyα emission]] much like distant, high-redshift galaxies observed in a younger universe.<ref name=Henry15/> Henry et al. explored the physical mechanisms that determine how Lyα escapes from the Green Peas, and concluded that variations in the neutral hydrogen column density were the most important factor.<ref name=Henry15/> More details here: [[Pea galaxy#Lyman Alpha Emission from Green Peas|Lyman Alpha Emission from Green Peas]].
===2016===
In May 2016, author Miranda C. P. Straub published a research paper in the [[open access journal]] Citizen Science: Theory and Practice called 'Giving Citizen Scientists a Chance: A Study of Volunteer-led Scientific Discovery'.<ref name=M.S._1>{{cite journal| title=Giving Citizen Scientists a Chance: A Study of Volunteer-led Scientific Discovery| author=M.C.P. Straub| journal=Citizen Science: Theory and Practice| date=20 May 2016| volume=1| issue=1| page=5| doi=10.5334/cstp.40}}</ref> The abstract states: "The discovery of a class of galaxies called Green Peas provides an example of scientific work done by volunteers. This unique situation arose out of a science crowdsourcing website called Galaxy Zoo."<ref name=M.S._1/>
In April 2016, Yang et al. published "Green Pea Galaxies Reveal Secrets of Lyα Escape."<ref name=HuanYang_1>{{cite journal| title=Green pea Galaxies Reveal Secrets of Lyman-alpha Escape| author1=Huan Yang| author2=S. Malhotra| author3=M. Gronke| author4=J.E. Rhoads| author5=M. Dijkstra| author6=A. Jaskot| author7=Zhenya Zheng| author8=Junxian Wang| journal=The Astrophysical Journal| volume=820| issue=2| pages=130| date=April 2016| arxiv=1506.02885| doi=10.3847/0004-637X/820/2/130| bibcode=2016ApJ...820..130Y}}</ref> Archival Lyman-alpha spectra of 12 GPs that have been observed with the HST/COS were analysed and modelled with radiative transfer models. The dependence of Lyman-alpha (LyA) escape fractions on various properties were explored. All 12 GPs show LyA lines in emission, with a LyA equivalent width distribution similar to high-redshift emitters.<ref name=HuanYang_1/> Among the findings are that the LyA escape fraction depends strongly on metallicity and moderately on dust extinction. The papers results suggest that low H1 column density and low metallicity are essential for LyA escape. "In conclusion, GPs provide an unmatched opportunity to study LyA escape in LyA Emitters."<ref name=HuanYang_1/>
===2017===
[[File:X-Ray Observations of Green Pea Analogs by Brorby et al.png| thumbnail|Combined images of J0842+1150 and SHOC 486 using Chandra x-ray and Hubble Space Telescope data. From Brorby and Kaaret AAS#229 2017]] In a presentation to the [[American Astronomical Society]] Meeting #229 in January 2017, Matt Brorby and Philip Kaaret describe the observations of two GPs and their x-ray emission.<ref name=Brorby>{{cite journal| title=Green Peas emit X-rays: Extreme Star Formation in Early Universe Analog Galaxies| author1=M. Brorby| author2=P. Kaaret| journal=American Astronomical Society| volume=229| pages=222.02| date=2017| bibcode=2017AAS...22922202B| url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/314399124}}</ref> Using both space telescope programs [[Chandra]] GO: 16400764 and Hubble GO: 13940, they examine Luminous Compact Galaxies, both GPs, J0842+1150 and SHOC 486. They conclude: 1) These are the first x-ray observations of GPs.<ref name=Brorby/> 2) The two GPs studied are the first test of Lx-SFR-Z planar relation and that they are consistent with this.<ref name=Brorby/> 3) Low metallicity galaxies exhibit enhanced x-ray emission relative to normal metallicity starforming galaxies.<ref name=Brorby/> 4) GPs are useful for predictions of X-ray output in the early universe.<ref name=Brorby/>
In March 2017, Yang et al. published a paper in [[the Astrophysical Journal]] called: "Lyα and UV Sizes of Green Pea Galaxies".<ref name=HuanYang_3>{{cite journal| title=Lyman-alpha and U.V. Sizes of Green Pea Galaxies| author1=Huan Yang| author2=S. Malhotra| author3=M. Gronke| author4=C. Leitherer| author5=A. Wofford| author6=Tianxing Jiang| author7=M. Dijkstra| author8=V. Tilvi| author9=Junxian Wang| journal=The Astrophysical Journal| volume=838| issue=1| pages=4| date=March 2017| arxiv=1610.05767| doi=10.3847/1538-4357/aa6337| bibcode=2017ApJ...838....4Y}}</ref> The authors studied the Lyman-alpha (LyA) escape in a statistical sample of 43 GPs with HST/COS LyA spectra, taken from 6 HST programs.<ref name=HuanYang_3/> Their conclusions include: 1) Using GPs that cover the whole ranges of dust extinction and metallicity, they find about two-thirds are strong LyA emitters. This confirms that GPs generally are "the best analogs of high-z (redshift) Lyman-alpha Emitters (LAEs) in the nearby universe."<ref name=HuanYang_3/> The LyA escape fractions show anti-correlations with a few LyA kinematic features. 3) The authors find many correlations regarding the dependence of LyA escape on galactic properties, such as dust extinction and metallicity.<ref name=HuanYang_3/>) The single shell radiative transfer model can reproduce most LyA profiles of GPs.<ref name=HuanYang_3/>) An empirical linear relation between the LyA escape fraction, dust extinction and the LyA red peak velocity.<ref name=HuanYang_3/>
In August 2017, Yang et al. published a study in the Astrophysical Journal called: "Lyα profile, dust, and prediction of Lyα escape fraction in Green Pea Galaxies".<ref name=HuanYang_2>{{cite journal| title=Lyα profile, dust, and prediction of Lyα escape fraction in Green Pea Galaxies| author1=Huan Yang| author2=S. Malhotra| author3=M. Gronke| author4=J.E. Rhoads| author5=C. Leitherer| author6=A. Wofford| author7=Tianxing Jiang| author8=M. Dijkstra| author9=V. Tilvi| author10=Junxian Wang| journal=[[The Astrophysical Journal]]| volume=844| issue=2| pages=15| date=August 2017| arxiv=1701.01857| bibcode=2017ApJ...844..171Y| doi=10.3847/1538-4357/aa7d4d| hdl=10852/60241}}</ref> The authors state that GPs are nearby analogues of high redshift Lyman-alpha (LyA)- emitting galaxies.<ref name=HuanYang_2/> Using spectral data from the HST-COS MAST archive, 24 GPs were studied for their LyA escape and the spatial profiles of LyA and UV continuum emissions.<ref name=HuanYang_2/> Results include: 1) Having compared LyA and UV sizes from the 2D spectra and 1D spatial profiles, it is found that most GPs show more extended LyA emission than the UV continuum. 2) 8 GPs had their spatial profiles of LyA photons at blueshifted and redshifted velocities compared. 3) The LyA escape fraction was compared with the size ration of LyA to UV. It was found that GPs that have LyA escape fractions greater than 10% "tend to have more compact LyA morphology".<ref name=HuanYang_2/>
In October 2017, Lofthouse et al. published a study in the [[Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society]] named:<ref name=Lofthouse>{{cite journal| title=Local analogues of high-redshift star-forming galaxies: integral field spectroscopy of green peas| author1=E.K. Lofthouse| author2=R.C.W. Houghton| author3=S. Kaviraj| journal=[[Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society]]| volume=471| issue=2| pages=2311–2320| arxiv=1701.07015| bibcode=2017MNRAS.471.2311L|doi=10.1093/mnras/stx1627| year=2017| hdl=2299/19471}}</ref> The authors used integral field spectroscopy, from the SWIFT and Palm 3K instruments, to perform a spatially-resolved spectroscopic analysis of four GPs, numbered 1,2,4 and 5.<ref name=Lofthouse/> Among the results are that GPs 1 & 2 are rotationally-supported (they have a rotating centre), while GPs 4 & 5 are dispersion-dominated systems.<ref name=Lofthouse/> GPs 1 & 2 show morphologies indicative of ongoing or mergers. However, GPs 4 & 5 show no signs of recent interactions and have similar star-forming rates. This indicates mergers are not "a necessary requirement for driving the high star formation in these types of galaxies".<ref name=Lofthouse/>
In December 2017, authors Jaskot, Oey, Scarlata and Dowd published a paper in the Astrophysical Journal Letters titled:"Kinematics and Optical Depth in the Green Peas: Suppressed Superwinds in Candidate LyC Emitters".<ref name=KinOp>{{cite journal| title=Kinematics and Optical Depth in the Green Peas: Suppressed Superwinds in Candidate LyC Emitters| author1=A.E. Jaskot| author2=M.S. Oey| author3=C. Scarlata| author4=T. Dowd| journal=The Astrophysical Journal Letters| volume=851|issue=1| pages=6| date=December 2017| arxiv=1711.09516| bibcode=2017ApJ...851L...9J| doi=10.3847/2041-8213/aa9d83}}</ref> Within the paper, they say that current thinking describes how superwinds clear neutral gas away from young starburst galaxies, which in turn regulates the escape of Lyman Continuum photons from star-forming galaxies. Models predict however that in the most extreme compact starbursts, those superwinds may not launch. The authors explore the role of outflows in generating low optical depth in GPs, using observations from the Hubble Space Telescope.<ref name=KinOp/> They compare the kinematics of ultraviolet absorption and with Lyman alpha escape fraction, Lyman alpha peak separation or low-ionisation absorption. The most extreme GPs show the slowest velocities, which "are consistent with models for suppressed superwinds, which suggests that outflows may not be the only cause of LyC escape from galaxies."<ref name=KinOp/>
== J0925+1403 and LyC Leakage ==
In January 2016, a letter was published in the journal [[Nature (journal)|Nature]] called: "Eight per cent leakage of Lyman continuum photons from a compact, star-forming dwarf galaxy" by authors: Y.I. Izotov, I. Orlitová, D. Schaerer, T.X. Thuan, A. Verhamme, N.G. Guseva & G. Worseck.<ref name=J0925_Nature>{{cite journal| author=Y.I. Izotov| author2=I. Orlitova| author3=D. Schaerer| author4=T.X. Thuan| author5=A. Verhamme| author6=N.G. Guseva| author7=G. Worseck| title=Eight per cent leakage of Lyman continuum photons from a compact, star-forming dwarf galaxy| date=2016| journal=Nature| volume=529| issue=7585| pages=178–180| doi=10.1038/nature16456| arxiv=1601.03068|bibcode = 2016Natur.529..178I| pmid=26762455}}</ref> The abstract states: "One of the key questions in observational cosmology is the identification of the sources responsible for ionisation of the Universe after the cosmic Dark Ages".<ref name=J0925_Nature/> It also states: "Here we present far-ultraviolet observations of a nearby low-mass star-forming galaxy, J0925+1403, selected for its compactness and high excitation... The galaxy is 'leaking' ionising radiation, with an escape fraction of 7.8%."<ref name=J0925_Nature/> These levels of radiation are thought to be similar to those of the first galaxies in the universe, which emerged in a time known as [[reionization]]. These findings have led the research team to conclude that J0925 can ionise intergalactic material up to 40 times its own stellar mass.<ref name=J0925_Nature/> The study was a result of observations carried out using the Cosmic Origins Spectrograph aboard the Hubble Space Telescope.<ref name=Thuan_HST>{{ cite web| title=Green Peas and diagnostics for Lyman continuum leaking in star-forming dwarf galaxies| author=Trinh Thuan| url=http://archive.stsci.edu/proposal_search.php?id=13744&mission=hst| publisher=Barbara A. Mikulski Archive for Space Telescopes| accessdate=13 October 2014}}</ref>
GP J0925 is thought to be similar to the most distant, and thus earliest, galaxies in the universe and has been shown to 'leak' LyC.<ref name=PhysOrg1>{{cite web| title=Green pea galaxy provides insights to early universe evolution| url=http://phys.org/news/2016-01-big-revealed-early-universe.html| publisher=phys.org| date=13 January 2016| accessdate=16 January 2016}}</ref><ref name=SpDa1>{{cite web| title=Green pea galaxy right after the Big Bang| url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2016/01/160113144548.htm| publisher=Science Daily| date=13 January 2016| accessdate=16 January 2016}}</ref><ref name=CSM1>{{Cite journal| author=K.Warner| title=What a tiny green galaxy reveals about the mysteries of the cosmos| journal=Christian Science Monitor| url=http://www.csmonitor.com/Science/2016/0114/What-a-tiny-green-galaxy-reveals-about-the-mysteries-of-the-cosmos| date=14 January 2016| accessdate=16 January 2016}}</ref> It is about 3 billion light years away (redshift z=0.301), or approximately 75% of the current age of the universe.<ref name=J0925_Nature/><ref name=CSM1/> Co-author Trinh Thuan said in a statement: "The finding is significant because it gives us a good place to look for probing the reionization phenomenon, which took place early in the formation of the universe that became the universe we have today".<ref name=CSM1/> He also stated: "As we make additional observations using Hubble, we expect to gain a much better understanding of the way photons are ejected from this type of galaxy, and the specific galaxy types driving cosmic reionization."<ref name=CSM1/> He concludes: "These are crucial observations in the process of stepping back in time to the early universe."<ref name=CSM1/>
===LyC Detection in J1152+3400, J1333+6246, J1442-0209, J1503+3644===
In October 2016, a study was published in the [[Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society|MNRAS]] entitled: "Detection of high Lyman continuum leakage from four low-redshift compact star-forming galaxies". Its authors are Y. I. Izotov, D. Schaerer, T. X. Thuan, G. Worseck, N. G. Guseva, I. Orlitova, A. Verhamme.<ref name="Detect_LyC"/> The abstract states: "Following our first detection reported in Izotov et al. (2016) [as above], we present the detection of Lyman continuum (LyC) radiation of four other compact star-forming galaxies observed with the Cosmic Origins Spectrograph (COS) onboard the Hubble Space Telescope (HST)".
This study contains the methods and findings from Izotov et al. 2016 (a) which concentrated on one galaxy, whereas the above paper, Izotov et al. 2016 (b) has findings for four galaxies, all of which have LyC leakage. When compared with other known local galaxies that leak LyC, as listed in this article, Izotov et al. 2016 (a & b) doubles the numbers of known leakers.<ref name=Detect_LyC/><ref name=J0925_Nature/>
== Lyman Alpha Emission from Green Peas == [[File:Greenpea lya.jpg |thumbnail|GP Spectra indicating the resonant scattering of Lyα photons.]] In May 2015, authors Alaina Henry, Claudia Scarlata, Crystal Martin, and Dawn Erb published a paper titled: "Lyα Emission from Green Peas: The Role of Circumgalactic Gas Density, Covering, and Kinematics".<ref name=Henry15/> The motivation of this work was to understand why some galaxies have Lyα emission, while others don't. A host of physical conditions in galaxies regulate the output of this spectral feature; hence, understanding its emission is fundamentally important for understanding how galaxies form and how they impact their intergalactic surroundings.
Henry et al. hypothesized that, since the GPs seem more like galaxies at redshift=z>2, and Lyα is common at these redshifts, that Lyα would be common in the GPs as well. Observations with the HST using the COS, as in 'Description', proved this to be true for a sample of 10 GPs.<ref name=Henry15/> The spectra, shown here to the right, indicate resonant scattering of Lyα photons that are emitted near zero velocity. The wealth of data existing on the GPs, combined with the COS spectra, allowed Henry et al. to explore the physical mechanisms that regulate the Lyα output. These authors concluded that variations in the amount of neutral hydrogen gas, which scatters Lyα photons, are the cause of a factor of 10 difference in Lyα output in their sample.<ref name=Henry15/>
The spectrum of GP_J1219 (an image of which is in 'Description') shows its very strong flux measurements when compared to other 9 GPs.<ref name=Henry15/> Indeed, only GP_J1214 has a value approaching that of J1219. Note also the double peaks in some GPs and the velocity values of the emissions, indicating the inflow and outflow of matter in the GPs.<ref name=Henry15/>
== Two papers by A. Jaskot and M.S. Oey ==
In April 2013, authors A. Jaskot and M. Oey published a paper in [[The Astrophysical Journal]] titled "The Origin and Optical Depth of Ionizing Radiation in the "Green Pea" Galaxies".<ref name="Jaskot"/> Six "extreme" GPs are studied. Using these, they endeavour to narrow down the list of possibilities about what is producing the UV-radiation and the substantial amounts of high-energy [[photon]] that might be escaping from the GPs.<ref name=Jaskot/> Through trying to observe these photons in nearby galaxies such as the GPs, our understanding of how galaxies behaved in the early Universe might well be revolutionised. It is reported that the GPs are exciting candidates to help astronomers understand a major milestone in the development of the cosmos 13 billion years ago, during the epoch of [[reionization]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Michigan_Uni_PR|url=http://www.ns.umich.edu/new/releases/21352-green-pea-galaxies-could-help-astronomers-understand-early-universe|accessdate=2014-03-27|publisher=[[University of Michigan]]|date=2013-04-03}}</ref>
In February 2014, authors A. Jaskot and M. Oey published a conference report titled "The Origin and Optical Depth of Ionizing Photons in the Green Pea Galaxies".<ref name="Jaskot_GH2013"/> This will appear in "Massive Young Star Clusters Near and Far: From the Milky Way to Reionization", based on the 2013 [[Guillermo Haro]] Conference. In the publication, Jaskot and Oey write: "We are currently analyzing observations from IMACS and MagE on the [[Magellan Telescopes]] and COS and ACS on [[Hubble Space Telescope]] (HST) to distinguish between WR ([[Wolf-Rayet star]]) and the shock ionization scenarios and confirm the GPs’ [[optical depth]]s.<ref name=Jaskot_GH2013/> The absence of WR features in the deeper IMACS spectra tentatively supports the shock scenario, although the detection limits do not yet definitively rule out the WR [[photoionization]] hypothesis."<ref name=Jaskot_GH2013/>
== Physics from the Cardamone 2009 paper == [[File:Pea Star Formation.jpg|thumb|Graph showing specific star formation rate plotted against galaxy mass, with the GPs (purple diamonds) and the Galaxy Zoo Merger Sample (black points)]]
At the time this paper was published, only five Green Peas (GPs) had been imaged by the [[Hubble Space Telescope]] (HST). Three of these images reveal GPs to be made up of bright clumps of star formation and low surface density features indicative of recent or ongoing [[galaxy merger]]s.<ref name=gzdiscovery/> These three HST images were imaged as part of a study of local [[ultraviolet]] (UV-luminous) galaxies in 2005.<ref name=T.H._05>{{ cite journal | display-authors=5| author1=T.M. Heckman| author2=C.G. Hoopes| author3=M. Seibert| author4=C. Martin| author5=S. Salim| author6=R.M. Rich| author7=G. Kauffmann| author8=S. Charlot| author9=T.A. Barlow| author10=L. Bianchi| author11=Y.-I. Byun| author12=J. Donas| author13=K. Forster| author14=P.N. Jelinsky| author15=Y.-W. Lee| author16=B.F. Madore| author17=R.F. Malina| author18=B. Milliard| author19=P.F. Morrissey| author20=S.G. Neff| author21=D. Schiminovich| author22=O.H.W. Siegmund| author23=T. Small| author24=A.S. Szalay| author25=B.Y. Welsh| author26=T.K. Wyder | date=January 2005 | title=The Properties of Ultraviolet-Luminous Galaxies at the Current Epoch | journal=[[The Astrophysical Journal]] | volume=619 |issue=1 |pages=L35–L38 | bibcode=2005ApJ...619L..35H | doi=10.1086/425979 | arxiv=astro-ph/0412577}}</ref> Major mergers are frequently sites of active star-formation and to the right a graph is shown that plots specific star formation rate (SFR / Galaxy Mass) against galaxy mass.<ref>{{ cite journal | author=A. Bauer | author2=N. Drory | author3=G. Hill | author4=G. Feulner | date=2005 | title=Specific Star Formation Rates to Redshift 1.5| journal=[[The Astrophysical Journal]] | volume=621 |issue=2| bibcode=2005ApJ...621L..89B | doi=10.1086/429289 | arxiv=astro-ph/0412358 | pages=L89–L92}}</ref> In this graph, the GPs are compared to the 3003 mergers from the Galaxy Zoo Merger Sample (GZMS).<ref name="Darg 2009">{{ cite journal | author1=D.W. Darg| author2=S. Kaviraj| author3=C.J. Lintott| author4=K. Schawinski| author5=M. Sarzi| author6=S. Bamford| author7=J. Silk| author8=R. Proctor| author9=D. Andreescu| author10=P. Murray| author11=R.C. Nichol| author12=M.J. Raddick| author13=A. Slosar| author14=A.S. Szalay| author15=D. Thomas| author16=J. Vandenberg| date=January 2010 | title=Galaxy Zoo: The fraction of merging galaxies in the SDSS and their morphologies | journal=[[Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society]] | volume=401 |issue=2 |pages=1043–1056 | bibcode=2010MNRAS.401.1043D | doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2009.15686.x | arxiv=0903.4937}}</ref> It shows that the GPs have low masses typical of [[dwarf galaxy]] and much higher star-forming rates (SFR) when compared to the GZMS. The black, dashed line shows a constant SFR of {{Solar mass|10}}/yr (~10 solar masses). Most GPs have a SFR between 3 and {{Solar mass|30}}/yr (between ~3 and ~30 solar masses).
[[File:PeaAGN Graph ed.jpg|thumb|left|Graph showing 103 GPs plotted as Starburst galaxies (red stars), transition objects (green crosses) or A.G.N. (blue diamonds)]]
GPs are rare. Of the one million objects that make up GZ's image bank, only 251 GPs were found. After having to discard 148 of these 251 because of atmospheric contamination of their [[Astronomical spectroscopy|Stellar spectra]], the 103 that were left, with the highest [[signal-to-noise ratio]], were analyzed further using the classic emission line [[diagnosis|diagnostic]] by Baldwin, Phillips and Terlevich which separates starbursts and [[Active galactic nucleus|active galactic nuclei]].<ref>{{ cite journal | author=J. Baldwin | author2=M. Phillips | author3=R. Terlevich | date=1981 | title=Classification parameters for the emission-line spectra of extragalactic objects | journal=[[Publications of the Astronomical Society of the Pacific]] | volume=93 |issue=551 |page=5 | bibcode=1981PASP...93....5B | doi=10.1086/130766 }}</ref> 80 were found to be starburst galaxies.<ref name=gzdiscovery/> The graph to the left classifies 103 narrow-line GPs (all with SNR ≥ 3 in the emission lines) as 10 [[Active galactic nucleus|active galactic nuclei]] (blue diamonds), 13 transition objects (green crosses) and 80 starbursts (red stars). The solid line is: Kewley et al. (2001) maximal starburst contribution (labelled Ke01).<ref name=Kewley_2001>{{cite journal | author1=L.J. Kewley| author2=M.A. Dopita| author3=R.S. Sutherland| author4=C.A. Heisler| author5=J. Trevena | date=July 2001 | title=Theoretical Modeling of Starburst Galaxies| journal=[[The Astrophysical Journal]] | volume=556| issue=1| pages=121–140| bibcode=2001ApJ...556..121K | doi=10.1086/321545 | arxiv=astro-ph/0106324}}</ref><ref>{{ cite journal | author=B. Groves | author2=L. Kewley | date=2008 | title=Distinguishing Active Galactic Nuclei and Star Formation | editor=J.H. Knapen | editor2=T.J. Mahoney | editor3=A. Vazdekis| journal=[[Astronomical Society of the Pacific|ASP Conference Series]] | volume=390 |pages=283 | bibcode=2008ASPC..390..283G | arxiv=0707.0158}}</ref> The dashed line is: Kauffmann et al. (2003) separating purely star-forming objects from AGN (labelled Ka03).<ref name=G.Kauf_2003>{{cite journal| display-authors=5| author1=G. Kauffmann| author2=T.M. Heckman| author3=S.D.M. White| author4=S. Charlot| author5=C. Tremonti| author6=J. Brinchmann| author7=G. Bruzual| author8=E.W. Peng| author9=M. Seibert| author10=M. Bernardi| author11=M. Blanton| author12=J. Brinkmann| author13=F. Castander| author14=I. Csabai| author15=M. Fukugita| author16=Z. Ivezic| author17=J. Munn| author18=R. Nichol| author19=N. Padmanabhan| author20=A. Thakar| author21=D. Weinberg| author22=D. York| date=May 2003 | title=Stellar Masses and Star Formation Histories | journal=[[Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society]]| volume=341| issue=1| pages=33–53| bibcode=2003MNRAS.341...33K | doi=10.1046/j.1365-8711.2003.06291.x | arxiv=astro-ph/0204055}}</ref>
[[File:Peas Equiv Width ed.jpg|thumb|Histogram showing [OIII] Eq.Wth. of 10,000 comparison galaxies (red); 215 UV-luminous Galaxies (blue); GPs (green)]]
GPs have a strong [OIII] emission line when compared to the rest of their spectral continuum. In a [[Sloan Digital Sky Survey|SDSS]] spectrum, this shows up as a large peak with [OIII] at the top.<ref>{{ cite web | title=SDSS Spectra | url=http://cas.sdss.org/astro/en/get/specById.asp?id=219212317798170624 | publisher=[[Sloan Digital Sky Survey]] | accessdate=2010-01-17 }}</ref> The wavelength of [OIII] (500.7 nm) was chosen to determine the luminosities of the GPs using [[Equivalent width]] (Eq.Wth.). The histogram on the right shows on the horizontal scale the Eq.Wth. of a comparison of 10,000 normal galaxies (marked red), UV-luminous Galaxies (marked blue) and GPs (marked green).<ref name=gzdiscovery/> As can be seen from the histogram, the Eq.Wth. of the GPs is much larger than normal for even prolific starburst galaxies such as UV-luminous Galaxies.<ref name=Hoopes_2007>{{ cite journal | display-authors=5 | author1=C.G. Hoopes| author2=T.M. Heckman| author3=S. Salim| author4=M. Seibert| author5=C.A. Tremonti| author6=D. Schiminovich| author7=R.M. Rich| author8=D.C. Martin| author9=S. Charlot| author10=G. Kauffmann| author11=K. Forster| author12=P.G. Friedman| author13=P. Morrissey| author14=S.G. Neff| author15=T. Small| author16=T.K. Wyder| author17=L. Bianchi| author18=J. Donas| author19=Y-W. Lee| author20=B.F. Madore| author21=B. Milliard| author22=A.S. Szalay| author23=B.Y. Welsh| author24=S.K. Yi| date=December 2007 | title=The Diverse Properties of the Most Ultraviolet-Luminous Galaxies Discovered by GALEX | journal=[[The Astrophysical Journal]] | volume=173 |issue= 2|pages=441–456 | bibcode=2007ApJS..173..441H | doi=10.1086/516644 | arxiv=astro-ph/0609415}}</ref>
Within the Cardamone et al. paper, comparisons are made with other compact galaxies, namely Blue Compact Dwarfs Galaxies and UV-luminous Galaxies, at local and much higher distances.<ref>{{ cite journal | author=O. Vaduvescu | author2=M. McCall | author3=M. Richer | date=2007 | title=Chemical Properties of Star-Forming Dwarf Galaxies| journal=[[The Astronomical Journal]] | volume=134 |issue=2 |pages=604–616 | bibcode=2007AJ....134..604V | doi=10.1086/518865 | arxiv=0704.2705 }}</ref> The findings show that GPs form a different class of galaxies than Ultra Blue Compact Dwarfs, but may be similar to the most luminous members of the Blue Compact Dwarf Galaxy category.<ref>{{ cite journal | author=M. Corbin | display-authors=etal | date=2006 | title=Ultracompact Blue Dwarf Galaxies: HST Imaging and Stellar Population Analysis| journal=[[The Astrophysical Journal]] | volume=651 |issue=2 |pages=861–873 | bibcode=2006ApJ...651..861C | doi=10.1086/507575 | arxiv=astro-ph/0607280 }}</ref> The GPs are also similar to UV-luminous high redshift galaxies such as Lyman-break Galaxies and [[Lyman-alpha emitter]].<ref>{{ cite journal | author=M. Bremer | display-authors=etal | date=2004 | title=The Properties of Galaxies at ''z''~5 | journal=[[Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society]] | volume=347 |issue=1 |pages=L7–L12 | bibcode=2004MNRAS.347L...7B | doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2004.07352.x | arxiv=astro-ph/0306587 }}</ref><ref>{{ cite journal | author=C. Gronwall | display-authors=etal | date=2007 | title=Lyα Emission-Line Galaxies at ''z'' = 3.1 in the Extended Chandra Deep Field-South | journal=[[The Astrophysical Journal]] | volume=667 |issue=1 |pages=79–91 | bibcode=2007ApJ...667...79G | doi=10.1086/520324 | arxiv=0705.3917 }}</ref><ref>{{ cite journal | author=L. Pentericii | display-authors=etal | date=2009 | title=The physical properties of Lyα emitting galaxies: not just primeval galaxies?| journal=Astronomy & Astrophysics | volume=494 |issue=2 |pages=553–561 | bibcode=2009A&A...494..553P | doi=10.1051/0004-6361:200810722 | arxiv=0811.1861 }}</ref> It is concluded that if the underlying processes occurring in the GPs are similar to that found in the UV-luminous high redshift galaxies, the GPs may be the last remnants of a mode of star formation common in the early Universe.<ref name=gzdiscovery/><ref>{{ cite journal | author=E. Gawiser | display-authors=etal | date=2007 | title=Lyα-Emitting Galaxies at ''z'' = 3.1: Progenitors Experiencing Rapid Star Formation | journal=Astrophysical Journal | volume=671 |issue= 1|pages=278–284 | bibcode=2007ApJ...671..278G | doi=10.1086/522955 | arxiv=0710.2697 }}</ref><ref>{{ cite journal | author=M. Giavalisco | display-authors=etal | date=2004 | title=The Rest-Frame Ultraviolet Luminosity Density of Star-forming Galaxies at Redshifts ''z'' > 3.51| journal=The Astrophysical Journal | volume=600 |issue=2 |pages=L103–L106 | bibcode=2004ApJ...600L.103G | doi=10.1086/381244 | arxiv=astro-ph/0309065 }}</ref>
[[File:Peas Reddening ed.jpg|thumb|Histogram showing reddening values for GPs]]
GPs have low [[Extinction (astronomy)|interstellar reddening]] values, as shown in the histogram on the right, with nearly all GPs having ''E''(''B''-''V'') ≤ 0.25. The distribution shown indicates that the line-emitting regions of star-forming GPs are not highly reddened, particularly when compared to more typical star-forming or starburst galaxies.<ref name=gzdiscovery/> This low reddening combined with very high UV luminosity is rare in galaxies in the local Universe and is more typically found in galaxies at higher redshifts.<ref name="Masters 2010">{{cite journal | author=K. Masters | display-authors=etal | date=2010 | title=Galaxy Zoo: Dust in Spirals | journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society| volume=404 |issue=2 |pages=792–810 | bibcode=2010MNRAS.404..792M | doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2010.16335.x | arxiv=1001.1744 }}</ref>
Cardamone et al. describe GPs as having a low metallicity, but that the oxygen present is highly ionized. The average GP has a metallicity of log[O/H]+12~8.69, which is solar ''or'' sub-solar, depending on which set of standard values is used.<ref name=gzdiscovery/><ref>{{ cite journal | author=N. Grevesse | author2=A. Sauval | date=1998 | title=Standard Solar Composition | journal=[[Space Science Reviews]] | volume=85 |issue= 1/2|pages=161–174 | bibcode=1998SSRv...85..161G | doi=10.1023/A:1005161325181 }}</ref><ref>{{ cite journal | author=C. Allende Prieto | author2=D.L. Lambert | author3=M. Asplund | date=2001 | title=The Forbidden Abundance of Oxygen in the Sun| journal=[[The Astrophysical Journal]] | volume=556 |issue=1 |pages=L63 | bibcode=2001ApJ...556L..63A | doi=10.1086/322874 | arxiv=astro-ph/0106360 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal| author=M. Asplund| author2=N. Grevesse| author3=A.J. Sauval | title=Cosmic abundances as records of stellar evolution and nucleosynthesis | date=2005| journal=ASP Conference Series| volume=336 |pages=1–4 | bibcode=2005ASPC..336...25A | doi=10.1016/j.nuclphysa.2005.06.010 | arxiv=astro-ph/0410214| citeseerx=10.1.1.255.9951}}</ref><ref>{{ cite journal | author=S. Basu | author2=H.M. Antia | year=2008 | title=Helioseismology and Solar Abundances | journal=Physics Reports | volume=457|issue= 5–6|pages=217–283 | bibcode=2008PhR...457..217B | doi=10.1016/j.physrep.2007.12.002 | arxiv=0711.4590 }}</ref> Although the GPs are in general consistent with the mass-metallicity relation, they depart from it at the highest mass end and thus do not follow the trend. GPs have a range of masses, but a more uniform metallicity than the sample compared against.<ref name="Tremonti 2004">{{ cite journal | author=C. Tremonti | display-authors=etal | date=2004 | title= The Origin of the Mass-Metallicity Relation: Insights from 53,000 Star-forming Galaxies in the Sloan Digital Sky Survey | journal=The Astrophysical Journal | volume=613 |issue= 2|pages=898–913 | bibcode=2004ApJ...613..898T | doi=10.1086/423264 | arxiv=astro-ph/0405537 }}</ref> These metallicities are common in low mass galaxies such as Peas.<ref name=gzdiscovery/>
[[File:GANDALF 587724241767825591 ed.jpg|thumb|left|An example of a GP spectrum made using GANDALF.]]
As well as the optical images from the SDSS, measurements from the [[GALEX]] survey were used to determine the ultraviolet values.<ref>{{ cite web | date=2003 | title=GALEX Observes the Universe| url=http://www.nasa.gov/missions/deepspace/galex_mission.html | publisher=[[NASA]] | accessdate=2010-01-16 }}</ref> This survey is well matched in depth and area, and 139 of the sampled 251 GPs are found in GALEX Release 4 (G.R.4).<ref>{{ cite journal | author=P. Morrissey | display-authors=etal | date=2007 | title=The Calibration and Data Products of GALEX | journal=Astrophysical Journal Supplement | volume=173 |issue= 2|pages=682–697 | bibcode=2007ApJS..173..682M | doi=10.1086/520512 }}</ref> For the 56 of the 80 star-forming GPs with GALEX detections, the median luminosity is ~30,000 million <math> L_{\odot} </math> (~30,000 million solar luminosities).
When compiling the Cardamone paper, spectral classification was made using Gas And Absorption Line Fitting (GANDALF).<ref name=gzdiscovery/> This sophisticated computer software was programmed by Marc Sarzi, who helped analyze the SDSS spectra.<ref>{{ cite journal | author=M. Sarzi | display-authors=etal | date=2006 | title=The SAURON Project – V. Integral-field emission-line kinematics of 48 elliptical and lenticular galaxies| journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society | volume=366 | issue=4 |pages=1151–1200 | bibcode=2006MNRAS.366.1151S | doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2005.09839.x | arxiv=astro-ph/0511307 }}</ref>
== Analysis of the Cardamone 2009 paper ==
These values are from Table 4, pages 16–17 of Cardamone 2009 et al., which shows the 80 GPs that have been analysed here.<ref name=gzdiscovery/> The long 18-digit numbers are the [[Sloan Digital Sky Survey|SDSS]] DR7 reference numbers. [[File:Colour Split 2.jpg|thumb|r-i vs. g-r color-color diagram for 251 GPs (green crosses), a sample of normal galaxies (red points) and all [[quasar]] (purple points)]]
